title: Raw Material Extraction and Ethical Concerns

evidences.text: So one of the issues is this massive reliance on raw material.
We talked about the material concerns in terms of these devices.
There have been more and more complexity added to these devices.
It used to be that only 10 elements were used in phones in the 1960s.
But now there's about 27 in 1990 and by 2021 it was 63.
The number of components and requirements are such that they say that 800 kg of raw materials are combined only to make a 2 kilogram laptop.
So that extraction especially of rare earth elements and certain other minerals like cobalt becomes a real limiting factor.
Another problematic minerals, cobalt.
This one, a lot of it's in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
And so they do believe that by having all the mining 84% in one single country by 2030 is an expectation; it's going to be problematic in terms of geopolitical risk.
A bigger picture though, is what this type of cobalt refinement means for the use of exploitation of labor.
There was a app for 2012 called the Dodd Frank act that looked at requiring companies to reveal where they get their raw materials from.
Supply chains are conflict free.
But cobalt was not included.
And so in 2014, Amnesty International found that around 20% of the cobalt being extracted from the DRC came from mines that use child labor.

And so Apple in 2017 pledged to treat cobalt as a conflict mineral as well and try and reform its supply chain to be able to eliminate child labor and unethical practices and trying to recover rare earth elements instead of trying to rely solely on new extraction.
So with elements like this, where we have sort of pockets where its availability is high in developing countries, the question for us ethically is what is right for us to do.

Is it exploitation because we're taking advantage of of their situation to try to get those minerals, or is it opportunity because we're trying to provide a source of income that will help the developing countries?
Something I want you to think about rare earth elements.

With such a low recycling rate as well, it can contain radioactive elements.

And what that does in terms of extraction is if you've got this incredibly valuable natural resource in your country, you're trying to extract it as quickly as you can, trying to make money off of it, trying to improve your economy, but it has potential to contaminate your local water and soil.
Is that being done in a manner that is allowing your people in your country to live as healthily as they can, or is it being done in a way that is exploitative?
Do we think that our processes of let's get this however we can is exploitative and we need to be careful of things like child labor.
